I for one 100% agree that reading system properties during a static initializer leads to untestable-like code.  I think there are a few articles out there that frown against it.  No one likes dealing with the class loader if they don't have to.

However, using system properties in something like object construction is a good idea.  (In my opinion.)  In fact I like it soo much I'm going to blog about it.  But my first rough draft has the template you need.  (It is currently the second code snippet.)  The idea is to save the system properties in a before method and restore in an after method.  Then set the property you want to change before constructing the object.  In your case it would be before loading the class.

I'm leaving the class loading issues as an exercise for the reader.  (Cause I don't want to touch that.)

http://bigmikef.blogspot.com/2009/12/using-system-properties-in-test.html

P.S. This page will be filled out when I get home from work.

I'm not really suggesting you change the overall design of the public API, I'm just suggesting you have a way of injecting a different properties object, via say a package-private method or constructor, rather than the public API, which would use that same method to inject the System properties at class initialization.

Regarding the Suite option, you only need as many Suites as you have variations on the System property.

If none of this makes sense, you are indeed down to a custom class loader, but on my Java map custom class loaders are in the "there be dragons" area, so I can't really give you any good advice there.
